item.title: How Microsoft Lost Its Mojo: Steve Ballmer and Corporate America’s Most Spectacular Decline
item.dc:creator: magneticmediafed
item.description: I rather enjoyed this article, but there is a large section in the middle that details a practice at Microsoft called "stack ranking" wherein every team reviews its members twice a year and forces the manager to rank them in a bell-curve, even if all members performed exceptionally well. Apparently this is why Microsoft has, for a decade, remained stagnate or worse. The problem is that the article didn't answer the primary question of 'why' was this 'stack ranking' was used. There has to be some sort of business reason aside from an arbitrary and draconian way to not be productive. Did it start as something else and then spiral out of control? I don't get it.
item.dc:subject: Microsoft profile Steve-Ballmer Vanity-Fair awesome

item.title: When Craigslist Blocks Innovations - Disruptions - NYTimes.com
item.dc:creator: dannydb
item.description:
When Craigslist Blocks Innovations /
Nick Bilton:
So why hasn’t anyone managed to unseat Craigslist, a site that has barely changed in close to two decades?
It has dug an effective moat by cultivating an exaggerated image of “doing good” that keeps its customers loyal, while behind the scenes, it bullies any rivals that come near and it stifles innovation.
This is a great read that touched on a lot of questions I’ve had about the legality of Padmapper’s relationship to Craigslist, and I’m glad to see somebody call a spade a spade with regard to Craigslist’s bullying tactics.
How long can Craigslist continue to defend their incumbent position through legal threats while refusing to improve their UX?
/ on tumblr: http://blog.dannydebelius.com/post/28268200558/when-craigslist-blocks-innovations
item.dc:subject: ifttt tumblr

item.title: “Critical mass” vs “network effects” by Dalton Caldwell
item.dc:creator: orlick
item.description: It was fun to use at first, but within months of launch, the user community started to change. I remember that as it started to really grow, I began getting several new friend requests a day… all written in portuguese. As the community rapidly changed, a lot of early users, including me, stopped using the site. Check out these demographic charts if you think I am exaggerating.

item.title: Using fdesetup with Mountain Lion’s FileVault 2 « Der Flounder
item.dc:creator: tj
item.description:
With the release of Mountain Lion, Apple has introduced fdesetup, a new command-line tool for enabling, administering and disabling Apple’s FileVault 2 encryption. This tool gives Mac administrators a number of command-line abilities, including the following:
Enable or disable FileVault 2 encryption on a particular Mac Use an individual recovery key, an institutional recovery key, or both kinds of recovery key. Enable one or multiple user accounts at the time of encryption Get a list of FileVault 2-enabled users on a particular machine Add additional users after FileVault has been enabled Remove users from the list of FileVault enabled accounts Report on the status of FileVault 2 encryption or decryption
item.dc:subject: osx filevault 10.8
